questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a leading cause of mortality in children aged 1-4 years in developing countries?

choices.text: Diarrhoeal diseases
Respiratory infections
Malnutrition
Congenital anomalies

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Congenital Anomalies

 

Explanation:

Congenital anomalies are a cause of mortality in age 1-4 years, they are not among the leading causes in developing countries. They are more prevalent as leading causes of mortality in developed countries.

questions.text: Under which initiative in India are children screened for common health conditions such as birth defects, deficiencies, developmental delays, and diseases up to the age of 18 years?

choices.text: Anemia Mukt Bharat
Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)
Applied Nutrition Programme
Mid-day Meal

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 2) Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

Explanation:

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is an initiative promoting school health

  • Comprehensive health care for children aged from birth to 18 years by screening them for birth defects, diseases, deficiencies, and developmental delays.
  • Children identified with these conditions receive early intervention and follow-up care provided free of cost including surgeries.

Other initiatives promoting school health:

Anemia Mukt Bharat (Option 1) - Providing iron and folic acid supplements - under WIFS (Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation)

  • 5-9 year children: Weekly 1 IFA - 45 mg. of Fe + 400 mcg. of folic acid, sugar-coated - pink color. Biannual deworming with one tablet of Albendazole tablet 400 mg done during the National Deworming days once in 6 months (10 of Aug and 10 of Feb of every year)
  • Adolescent boys and girls - weekly 1 IFA - containing 100 mg Fe and 500 mcg of folic acid and biannual deworming with 1 tablet of 400 mg Albendazole.

Menstrual hygiene management:

  • Sanitary pads are provided to girls
  • Usually in rural areas

 

Nutritional Services:

PM POSHAN (POshan SHAkti Nirman) Scheme

  • Previously called as National Programme for Mid-Day Meal in Schools (Mid-Day Meal Scheme) (Option 4)
  • Provides one hot cooked meal (⅓ Calories, ½ protein) to school children studying in Classes I-VIII in Government and Government-aided schools. To prevent dropouts.

             

                                                                                MID DAY MEAL PROGRAM

Applied Nutrition Programme (Option 3):

In collaboration with UNICEF- Provides and implements seeds, manure, and water supply equipment to develop school gardens.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding a healthful school environment?

choices.text: Classrooms should accommodate no more than 40 students with a minimum of 10 sq. ft. per student.
The interior walls of classrooms should be colorfully painted to create a stimulating environment for students.
One urinal per 60 students, one latrine per 100 students must be provided. Separate facilities for boys and girls.
Site should be on high-lying land with an area of 10 acres for higher elementary schools, 5 acres for primary schools, with an additional 1 acre per 100 students.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 2) The interior walls of classrooms should be colorfully painted to create a stimulating environment for students

 

Explanation:

The interior walls of classrooms should be white-washed, not colorfully painted. White walls help in maintaining cleanliness and provide a calm environment in the classroom.
 

Healthful School Environment

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) is incorrect?

choices.text: KMC involves early and prolonged skin-to-skin contact between the infant and the mother.
KMC is meant for clinically stable low birth weight (LBW) infants and includes exclusive and frequent breastfeeding.
KMC should only be provided in hospitals under skilled supervision and proper guidance.
KMC helps stabilize body temperature, promotes breastfeeding, and prevents infections.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 3) KMC should only be provided in hospitals under skilled supervision and proper guidance.

 

Explanation:

KMC should be initiated in the hospital under skilled supervision but is intended to be continued at home to provide ongoing benefits to the infant.

 

Kangaroo Mother Care is a low-resource, high-impact intervention for low birth weight infants. It has the following benefits:- (Option 4)

  • Stabilizing the infant's body temperature and preventing hypothermia
  • Reducing neonatal mortality and risk of infections
  • Promoting effective breastfeeding
  • Reducing the length of hospital stay

Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) has 4 main components:-

  • Kangaroo Position- Prolonged skin-to-skin contact (Option 1)
  • Kangaroo Nutrition- Exclusive and frequent breastfeeding (Option 2)
  • Kangaroo Discharge- The infant is sent home early, as soon as the mother can provide all basic care.
  • Kangaroo support- Close follow-up and access to daily visits.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding artificial feeding in infants?

choices.text: The estimated protein requirement is about 2 g/kg of body weight during the first 6 months; Declines to about 1.5 g/kg by the end of one year.
Options used in artificial feeding include dried whole milk powder, fresh milk from a cow or other animal, or commercial formulae
Cow milk is the safest and most commonly used artificial feeding method in developing countries
The main indications for artificial feeding are failure of breast milk, prolonged illness or death of the mother.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 3) Cow milk is the safest and most commonly used artificial feeding method in developing countries.

 

Explanation:

While cow milk is a commonly used alternative for infant feeding in developing countries due to its availability and cost, it is not considered the safest option.

  • Cow milk contains higher levels of bacteria than dried milk powder
  • It requires dilution to reduce the solute load on neonatal kidneys
  • It lacks certain essential nutrients that are present in breast milk or commercial formulae, which are specifically designed to meet the nutritional needs of infants.

Artificial Feeding Options (Option 2)

  • Dried Whole Milk Powder
  • Fresh Milk from a Cow or Other Animal
  • Commercial Formulae
  • Donor Human Milk

Nutritional Requirements and Feeding Guidelines for Infants

Requirement/Guideline

Details

Energy Requirement
  • Infants require an average of 100 kcal per kg of body weight per day (about 150 ml of milk per kg of body weight each day).

Protein Requirement
  • 2 g/kg of body weight during the first 6 months.
  • Declines to about 1.5 g/kg by the end of one year. (Option 1)

Feeding Frequency
  • Infants need feeding at frequent intervals about 6-8 times a day.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect when comparing human milk to cow milk?

choices.text: Human milk contains 3 times lower protein, but is rich in amino acids like cysteine and taurine, essential for infants.

Correct Answer: 3) The coefficient of uptake of iron is equal in both breast and cow milk, however, breast milk contains more Vitamin A and C.

 

Explanation:

This statement is incorrect. The coefficient of uptake of iron is not equal in both breast and cow milk. Human milk has a higher bioavailability of iron compared to cow milk. Additionally, human milk does contain more Vitamin A and C compared to cow milk.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of poor dietary intake for the past several months. On examination, the child has Bitot's spots and other signs of vitamin A deficiency. What is the most appropriate treatment plan for this child to correct the Vitamin A deficiency?

choices.text: Administer a single dose of 50,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and repeat the dose the next day.
Administer a single dose of 100,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and another dose of 100,000 IU after 9 months.
Administer 50,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and repeat this dose every 6 months until the child turns 5 years.
Administer 200,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and the very next day. If clinical signs persist, third dose of 200,000 IU 2-4 weeks later.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4) Administer 200,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and the very next day. If clinical signs persist, give a third dose of 200,000 IU 2-4 weeks later.

Explanation:

Immediate High Dose: The initial high dose of 200,000 IU is necessary to rapidly replenish vitamin A levels in the body, addressing the acute deficiency and preventing further deterioration.

Follow-Up Dose: Repeating the dose the next day ensures that the body receives a sufficient amount of vitamin A to start correcting the deficiency effectively. 2 Doses are mostly sufficient to reverse the ocular signs of Vitamin A deficiency.

Third Dose if Needed: A third dose after 2-4 weeks may be required if clinical signs persist, ensuring that the deficiency is fully corrected.

≥ 12 months

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with bilateral pedal edema, severe wasting, and a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) of 10.5 cm. Which of the following is the feature of initial management of this condition?

choices.text: Focus on nutritional and electrolyte balance
Starter Diet provides 100 kcal per 1000 ml
Initiation of a home-based nutritious diet
Provide a catch up diet like F-100

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1) Focus on nutritional and electrolyte balance


Explanation:

The clinical features described in the question, including bilateral pedal edema, severe wasting, and a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) of 10.5 cm, are suggestive of severe acute malnutrition (SAM)

 

The clinical features described in the question, including bilateral pedal edema, severe wasting, and a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) of 10.5 cm, are suggestive of severe acute malnutrition (SAM)

The first step in the treatment of SAM, particularly in an inpatient setting, involves correcting electrolyte imbalances (such as low potassium or sodium), rehydration, and replenishing micronutrient deficiencies before initiating feeding.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding growth charts is false?

choices.text: The position of dots is more important than direction
Flattening of the curve is a sign of growth failure
0 to -2 SD signifies normal growth
50th percentile is the upper reference for boys in the WHO growth chart

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1) The position of dots is more important than direction

 

Explanation:

The direction of the curve is more important than the position of the dots as it focuses on the trajectory of a child's growth over time, and helps identify if a child is growing steadily, experiencing rapid growth, or potentially showing signs of growth faltering.

Features of ICDS growth chart :

CRITERIA FOR ICDS GROWTH CHART

0 to -2 SD

  • Road to health
  • Green color
  • Advice: Take care of danger signs.

-2 to -3 SD

  • Mild to moderate malnutrition
  • Yellow color
  • Advice: Supplement with diet and breastfeeding.

Below -3 SD

  • Severe malnutrition
  • Red color
  • Refer to a CHC level or above

FEATURES OF ICDS GROWTH CHART

  • Has 3 lines
  • Weight is on the y-axis
  • Age is on the x-axis
  • The first sign of growth failure is the flattening of the curve.
  • The direction of the growth chart is more important than the position of the dots.

 

 

Features of WHO GROWTH CHART :

  • Upper reference (50th percentile for boys)
  • Lower reference (3rd percentile for girls)
  • Between the two references - Normal growth
  • Below lower reference - Malnutrition

choices.text: MUAC < 11.5 cm

Absence of pitting pedal edema
Presence of severe body wasting

questions.solution:

SAM children meeting these criteria are to be admitted to Nutritional Rehabilitation Centres (NRCs) for treatment and care.

questions.text:
Non-clinical Question:

Match the following markers to the type of malnutrition they best assess:-


	
		
			
			Marker
			
			
			Type of Malnutrition
			
		
		
			
			a. Weight-for-height
			
			
			1. Chronic Malnutrition
			
		
		
			
			b. Height-for-age
			
			
			2. Acute Malnutrition
			
		
		
			
			C. Weight-for-age
			
			
			3. Acute on chronic malnutrition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 3) 1-b, 2-a, 3-c

Explanation:

  • Weight-for-height assesses acute malnutrition (wasting).
  • Height-for-age assesses chronic malnutrition (stunting).
  • Weight-for-age is an overall indicator but does not differentiate between acute and chronic malnutrition, making it less specific for either.
  • Head circumference is a general indicator that can reflect both acute and chronic malnutrition, but it's not the primary marker for either.

questions.text: What is the  minimum number of antenatal visits recommended by the WHO?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 3) 8

Explanation:

According to the WHO, the minimum number of antenatal visits (or Antenatal care contact) is 8.

Schedule of visits:

  • 1st Trimester: 1 visit ( in the first 12 weeks)
  • 2nd Trimester: 2 visits ( at 20 & 26 weeks)
  • 3rd Trimester: 5 visits ( at 30, 34, 36, 38 and 40 weeks)

It is recommends that pregnant women have their first contact in the first 12 weeks of gestation, with subsequent contacts taking place at 20, 26, 30, 34, 36, 38, and 40 weeks’ gestation.

The minimum number of visits per MOHFW is 4.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE with respect to mortality rates in children?

choices.text: The most common cause of neonatal mortality is low birth weight.
Sepsis is a significant cause of both neonatal and infant mortality.
The Infant Mortality Rate is considered the best indicator of socio-economic development by UNICEF.
Current IMR is 28/1000 live births.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 3) The Infant Mortality Rate is considered the best indicator of socio-economic development by UNICEF.

 

Explanation:

UNICEF considers the Under-5 Mortality Rate, not the Infant Mortality Rate, as the single best indicator of overall socio-economic development and well-being of society.

  • Low birth weight/ prematurity is recognized as the most common cause of neonatal mortality, infant mortality as well as Under-5 Mortality Rate.
  • Sepsis is a significant cause of mortality in both neonates and infants.
  • The current Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) in India is 28 per 1000 live births as given by the sample registration system.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Perinatal Mortality Rate (PMR) is FALSE?

choices.text: PMR includes late fetal deaths from 28 weeks of gestation and early neonatal deaths within the first 7 days of life.
PMR is considered the best indicator for combined obstetrics and pediatrics care.
The weight of the fetus should be at least 2 kg to be included in the PMR.
Birth asphyxia is a significant cause of perinatal mortality.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer:- 3) The weight of the fetus should be at least 2 kg to be included in the PMR.

Explanation:

According to the Criteria for PMR, the weight of the fetus should be at least 1 kg to be included in the PMR.

Criteria for PMR:

  • 28 weeks of gestation
  • The weight of the fetus should be at least 1 kg
  • Length of fetus at least 35 cm

 

Perinatal mortality rate = [Late fetal death (28 weeks of gestation) + early neonatal death (0 -7 days)] / live births x 1000 (Option 1).

PMR is the best indicator for combined obstetrics and pediatrics care, as it considers both. (Option 2)

Birth Asphyxia is a significant cause of Perinatal mortality. (Option 4)

questions.text: What is the current Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) in India according to the Sample Registration System (SRS)?

choices.text: 30 per 1000 live births
28 per 1000 live births
25 per 1000 live births
20 per 1000 live births

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 2) 28 per 1000 live births

Explanation:

In India, the current Infant mortality rate (IMR) is 28 per 1000 live births, as reported by the Sample Registration System (SRS).

 

Infant mortality rate (IMR) is expressed as the number of deaths of infants (aged 0-1 year) per 1000 live births in a given year.

Infant mortality rate (IMR) = (No. of deaths of children (infant) 0-1 year of life / live births) x 1000)

 

Causes:

  • The most common cause is low birth weight/prematurity according to the latest update
  • Other causes include asphyxia, ARIs, diarrhea, congenital anomalies, cord infection, birth trauma, and others.
  • Most infant deaths occur within the first month of life, with a significant proportion (54.6%) occurring during the first week.
  • The risk of death is highest within the first 24-48 hours after birth.
  • IMR reflects the effectiveness of maternal and child health (MCH) services and overall healthcare infrastructure in preventing infant deaths.

questions.text: Which of the following defines the Neonatal Mortality Rate?

choices.text: Death of a child within 0-28 days of life per 1000 live births
Death of a child within 0-7 days of life per 1000 live births
Death of a child within 8-28 days of life per 1000 live births
Death of a child within 29 days to 1 year of life per 1000 live births

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1) Death of a child within 0-28 days of life per 1000 live births

Explanation:

Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) measures the number of deaths of infants within the first 28 days of life per 1000 live births.

It is calculated as,

Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) = (No. of deaths of children (neonates) 0 – 28 days of life / live births) x 1000

Causes of Neonatal deaths:

  • Most common cause: low birth weight/ prematurity
  • Other causes:
    • Birth asphyxia/hypoxia
    • Neonatal pneumonia
    • Sepsis
    • Congenital anomalies
    • Diarrhea
    • Injuries
    • Other non-communicable diseases

 

  • Danger Signs:
    • Refusal to feed
    • Lethargy
    • Cold to touch
    • Difficult or rapid breathing
    • Convulsions
    • Persistent vomiting
    • Jaundice at birth
    • Blue color of extremities

Other Neonatal Mortality Indicators:

Early neonatal mortality rate

(Option 2)

(No. of deaths of children (neonate) 0 – 7 days of life / live births) x 1000)

Late neonatal mortality rate

(Option 3)

(No. of deaths of children (neonate) 8th – 28 days of

life / live birth) x 1000)

Post-neonatal mortality rate

(Option 4)

(No. of deaths of children (neonate) 29th day - 1 year of life / live births) x 1000)

questions.text: A state recorded 150 maternal deaths in a year. The number of live births during the same period was 50,000. The total number of women in the reproductive age group (15-49 years) is 10,00,000. What is the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for this state?

choices.text: 3.0 per 1,000 women of reproductive age
1.5 per 1,000 live births
300 per 100,000 live births
15 per 100,000 women of reproductive age

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 300 per 100,000 live births

 

Explanation:

The question specifically asks for the maternal mortality ratio.

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is the number of maternal deaths during the antenatal period, during delivery, and up to 42 days post delivery per 100,000 live births. It is calculated as follows:

Maternal Mortality Ratio =  ( No. of maternal deaths / No. of Live births )    x   100000

                                                   

 

So the answer will be, (150/50000) x 100000 = 300 (option 3)

Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) is the number of maternal deaths during the antenatal period, during delivery, and up to 42 days post-delivery per 1,00,000 women of reproductive age (aged 15-49 years) in a given period. It is calculated as follows:

Maternal Mortality Rate =   (Number of maternal deaths / No. of women in reproductive age group)   x    100000

                                                 

 

MM Rate with the given data will be

MM Rate = (150/1000000)x100000=15 (Option 4)

questions.text: Which maternal health initiative launched by the National Health Mission focuses on improving the quality of care in labor rooms and maternity operation theaters?

choices.text: Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA)
Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY)
Dakshata Training
LaQshya

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4)

 

Explanation:

LaQshya—Labour Room Quality Improvement Initiative—focuses on decreasing preventable maternal and newborn deaths, illnesses, and stillbirths by enhancing the quality of care during labor and delivery and ensuring respectful maternity care.

 

Objectives include:

  • Managing complications like APH, PPH, preterm labor, and sepsis
  • Improving care during delivery and the postpartum period
  • Ensuring prompt referrals
  • Promoting patient satisfaction and respectful treatment for all pregnant women in public health facilities

 

Other Maternal Health Initiatives:

Initiative

Aims

Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA)

(Option 1)

 

To offer free, comprehensive, and high-quality antenatal care to all pregnant women on the 9th of each month.

Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK)

Entitles all pregnant women giving birth in public health institutions to receive completely free services, including cesarean sections, and also covers free transportation.

Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) (Option 2)

To reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional deliveries among poor pregnant women through financial incentives.

SUMAN - Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan

Free, respectful healthcare with zero service denials, aiming to prevent maternal and newborn deaths. Beneficiaries include all pregnant women, up to 6 months post-delivery, and sick infants.

Dakshata Training

(Option 3)

A training program designed to enhance the skills and competencies of healthcare providers in intrapartum and immediate postpartum care.

questions.text:
A 28 y/o pregnant woman, currently at 24 weeks of gestation, visits you for her routine antenatal check-up. She reports feeling excessive thirst and has been urinating more frequently than usual. She also mentions occasional fatigue. Her obstetric history includes a previous pregnancy with a baby weighing 4.2 kg at birth.

 

Which of the following tests would you recommend for her?

choices.text: Random Blood Sugar Test (RBS)
Fasting Blood Sugar Test (FBS)
Oral glucose challenge test (OGCT)
HbA1c Test

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Oral glucose challenge test (OGCT)

Explanation:

The patient is in her 2nd trimester and has complaints of polydipsia and polyuria. She also has a history of giving birth to an overweight baby (Macrosomia). This suggests the possibility of her having Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM).

The OGCT is commonly used as a screening test for GDM.

  • Procedure: The patient is given a 50g oral glucose solution to drink. One hour after drinking the glucose solution, blood is drawn to measure blood glucose levels.
  • Interpretation: A 140 mg/dL or higher blood glucose level is considered abnormal and warrants further testing with an OGTT.

 

The OGTT (Oral Glucose Tolerance Test) is a diagnostic test for GDM.

OGTT is performed in the 1st antenatal visit and then repeated again at 24-28 weeks POG

  • Procedure: A fasting blood sample is drawn to measure the baseline glucose level. The patient drinks a 75g oral glucose solution. Blood samples are drawn one hour and two hours after drinking the glucose solution.
  • Interpretation: According to DIPSI guidelines, the diagnosis of GDM is made if any of the following plasma glucose values are met or exceeded:
    • Fasting: 92 mg/dL
    • 1 hour: 180 mg/dL
    • 2 hours: 153 mg/dL

This 2-step approach is widely recommended and provides a reliable method for diagnosing GDM.

 

RBS, FBS, and HbA1c tests (Options 1, 2, & 4) are less specific and commonly used for ruling out overt diabetes mellitus and diagnosing GDM.

questions.text: A 25 y/o primigravida, in her 2nd month of pregnancy, has come to you for her routine antenatal checkup. On further questioning, you find out that she has not been given any vaccinations yet. Which of the following is TRUE regarding vaccination protocols in pregnancy?

choices.text: A booster dose of the Td vaccine is enough for this patient
3 doses of Td vaccine must be given
1st Td dose should be given as soon as possible
2nd dose should be given 48 days after the 1st dose

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 3) 1st dose should be given as soon as possible

Explanation: Since she is a primi, the 1st Td dose should be given as soon as possible.

Vaccination protocol in pregnancy:

 

A booster dose of the Td vaccine is not enough for this patient because a booster dose is only given to multigravida mothers with last childbirth within 3 years (Option 1).

Only 2 doses of Td must be given in primigravida (Option 2).

The 2nd dose must be given after 28 days after the 1st dose, not after 48 days (Option 4).

questions.text: A 23 y/o woman, who works at a construction site, comes to you with obstetric code G1P0L0, in her 2nd trimester for her 2nd routine check-up. She is anemic and has a Hb value of 8.4g/dl. Which of the following would not be the right advice for her?

choices.text: She should take 1 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablet daily.
She should increase her calorie intake

She should increase her calcium and vitamin A intake

.
She must come for at least 2 more ANC visits

questions.solution:
Correct answer: 1) She should take 1 iron and folic acid tablet daily

Explanation: This patient is a primigravida & also she is anemic.

  • Pregnant women with normal Hb levels (>11 g/dl) must take 1 IFA tablet daily.
  • Whereas, all pregnant women with Hb between 7-9 g/dl must take 2 IFA tablets daily.
  • For mothers with < 7g/dl = injectables are given.

 

She needs to increase her calorie intake (Option 2) as per the nutritional Requirements in Pregnancy:

Calorie requirements according to NIN (National Institute of Nutrition)
  • Pregnancy: +350 kcal/day.
  • Lactation:
    • 0-6 months: +600 kcal/day.
    • 7-12 months: +520 kcal/day.

Ideal time
  • 1st trimester: No additional calories required.
  • 2nd trimester: 350 kcal/day.
  • 3rd trimester: 450 kcal/day.

Daily allowance for females
  • Sedentary: 1660 kcal.
  • Moderate: 2100 kcal.
  • Heavy worker: 2700 kcal.
    • +350 means we add to sedentary (1660).

Calcium and vitamin A intake should be increased (Option 3) because the nutrient requirements that increase during pregnancy and lactation are:

○ Calcium

○ Vitamin A

○ Iodine

She must come for at least 2 more ANC visits as the minimum number of ANC visits is 4, according to the Government of India (Option 4).

  • First visit: As soon as pregnancy is suspected, or within the first three months of a missed period
  • Second visit: Between 14–26 weeks
  • Third visit: Between 28–36 weeks
  • Fourth visit: Between 36 weeks and term
